pros: Fantastic benefits. Benefits at 20 hrs/ week, including health care, dental, vision, therapy, spotify, FULL COLLEGE TUITION REIMBURSEMENT via ASU, and the list goes on. Small stores in particular can feel like a home away from home, and it's a great place to learn communication skills, teamwork, and work ethic.
cons: Pay grade is lower than almost anyone in the same industry, and even lower than unemployment can pay (in some states). No incentive for working anything over the 20 hrs/ week for benefits, time better spent elsewhere. Company feels like it's lost the spirit for coffee and the cafe experience ever since Howard left as CEO. Now more than ever, the divide between corporate decision making and decisions made on-the-ground in stores seems wider and less unified.

review_title: We accept the exploitation, but they don't hold up their end - the bare minimum
pros: It's fun. Baristas are fun people, and everyone I work with is a close friend, simply because that's what it's like working at my store. It's also "in" - being a Starbucks barista is, at least somewhat, glamorous.
cons: First of all, the design of my store is an embarrassment. That is but one example of why I have to describe the Starbucks aristocracy as careless, and difficult to figure out. We accept the disgusting disparity between the profit we produce and the percentage of it we receive as payment, but they don't hold up their bare minimum. The store, as a mechanism needed to supply what their customers are paying for, is neglected. We have to make due with an insanely awkward and small amount of space, and tools that are either old and decrepit, or new equipment that is cheaply built. We need to be very careful to not cut ourselves on sharp pieces of equipment, not to trip over clutter as well as ourselves, burn ourselves due to overexposed water heaters on our espresso machines as well as insufficient tools and space for food, and we also have a problem with not being allowed to demand customers proper behavior from customers. Someone at my store was just fired for throwing a cup of water at someone who was charging at him in the parking lot - an incident that didn't even have anything to do with Starbucks.

pros: Starbucks offers many corporate benefits like 401K match, stock, health, dental & vision insurance along with other perks like a Spotify & Headspace subscription. They also reimburse you for tuition towards a Bachelor's with AZU. The benefits are offered at a cheap, affordable rate. I have worked with other employees from different locations and most are very nice because we all understand this is a stressful job.
cons: The starting hourly is lower than it is for fast food places in the surrounding area. The work has become especially stressful with the pandemic creating unpredictable peak hours. If you have a drive thru location, you can expect the flow to be nearly constant throughout the morning & afternoon. With people understaffed, a shift can quickly become exhausting (more so than other fast-paced food places I've worked at). The customers that come in can be extremely rude though Starbucks offers better customer service than most places...you sure wouldn't get a drink remade at McDonald's or get angry at the employees for things out of their control like prices, long lines or food shortages. We have a lot of decisions come down from corporate or district managers that don't always make sense given the reality of the work/expected efficiency of the position.

review_title: Good for a fast food joint, terrible for the soul
pros: Surprisingly alright benefits if you work enough hours, for a fast food joint. Pretty flexible scheduling which is very nice for students. If you want to move theres definitely going to be a Starbucks wherever you move to.
cons:
Tons of borderline illegal union-busting practices. The epitome of the corporate cult, pretending to care so much about their workers and social justice, while paying garbage wages and using slave labour for their products. Your experience is entirely based on your Store Manager and District Manager, the later of which in Victoria is so universally hated that I heard every store manager I worked under speak ill of her. 
Wages are minimum wage, and I've never worked somewhere with as bad tips as this. That wouldn't be the end of the world really, but when you're expected to put up with the amount of abuse from customers and management that you are at Starbucks, it wasn't worth it

review_title: Need to be stricter when it comes to protecting from Covid-19
pros: Flexible hours depending on the store manager
cons:
Had to repeatedly enforce certain days and hours I simply was not available, constantly being asked to work longer than scheduled shift to cover those that were late and when I couldn't consistently do so per family responsibilities I was told I was not a team player. I worked at a coffee shop before Starbucks and had dealt with high demand and fast pace before but shift managers I usually worked with were very aggressive in the way they spoke to teammates and consistently forgot or refused to give breaks and lunch because of the rush, to the point I or teammates would feel sick. Strict protocol put into place for the pandemic by the store manager, but it took hours of shift manager being told by team members to send a barista home who was sneezing and coughing all day. Took time off during the pandemic and went back to see Covid protocols were still not being safely reinforced 
Was a way to make ends meet while looking for another job after moving to the city, but would not want to return.

pros: Store manager & District manager were both great, coworkers were wonderful as well
cons:
The breaks were very short and the pace was incredibly fast and demanding. Too many side-tasks to juggle in a tiny space with many bodies. It was very stressful and overwhelming at times, after a while you're exhausted but you're running on autopilot. When you finally get some time off its not long enough to develop a life outside of the company.

At the corporate level, there is an intense focus on 'LEAN' principles and I understand the thinking behind this but its taken too far in some ways (budgeting a set number of hours for certain tasks which sets you up to fail and look bad if things happen during your task that you have to deal with). Working at starbucks was incredibly exhausting and I've worked long hours at restaurants and there's this unspoken expectation that management will work off-hours to get tasks done on their own time that they weren't budgeted for. It was an eye-opening experience but that lifestyle doesn't seem sustainable for personal development or mental health.

review_title: Not paid enough to run the store
pros:
Great atmosphere, Great benefits, Great opportunities.
Starbucks is a great company and trains its employees well.
Starbucks strives to help its employees grow and develop no matter what role they are in.
Starbucks also paid its employees Catastrophe pay during the height of the pandemic to support their partners, however that currently is not an option anymore due to the prolonged pandemic.
cons: Starbucks claims to be competitive in their pay, but across the board that is simply not true. You could do the same job (barista, shift supervisor, store manager) anywhere else and you will be paid more. As a shift supervisor, you basically run the store for your store manager, and you are not compensated for your efforts. Starbucks tries to get you with their benefits, but nowadays, you can get benefits anywhere.

pros: Fun environment meet new people

review_title: Nice people but too many responsibilities for the pay
pros: You get to meet nice coworkers and make drinks for people. Free coffee and a meal for you, even on your days off. Plus you get a bag of coffee every week. You also get tips based off of hours worked, so sometimes in nicer areas you'll make more in tips.
cons: Usually short staffed, very intense, and rushes are super draining. You have to get good and learn a million things before it becomes a doable job. The pay, at least in my area, is very low compared to all the responsibilities you carry. Also, the customers are generally kinda rude and never know what they want or what they're ordering. The crazy outages also don't help since you're generally gonna be out of at least 4 things every day. Breaks are only 10 minutes long, once per day, unless you work more than 6 hours, then you get 30.

pros:
- nice perks (free spotify premium, discounts when not working, free bag of coffee per week)
- understanding of mental health situations
- LOAs available
cons:
- pay is nowhere near high enough for the demands of the job
- environment was REALLY hit or miss. I worked at two different stores; very friendly and supportive partners at one, but incredibly rude partners & management at the other that actually led me to leave the company.
- if you don't quit one store and end up being hired at another location instead of transferring, they won't honor what you were paid previously. I was paid nearly $1.50/hr less once I switched to another (busier) store - and I was working harder.

pros: Free food and drinks, and a free pound of coffee weekly along with other great benefits.

I repeat you will not ever have priority, the manager will legit fire you if you try to buy a piece of merchandise that a customer wanted before you. Lastly, this is a very very fast-paced job and you are understaffed 95% of the time, also you will be paid under if not just the minimum wage for doing tons of work.

review_title: Great employer if you get a good store
pros:
Excellent health benefits so long as you average 20hr/week

Great perks such as 3 free drinks per shift, free pound of coffee a week, discounts for various things such as gym membership, insurance, or some retail stores, and 30% off all Starbucks purchases

Many people find opportunities for advancement if they want them

You get annual raises

They have a generous matching program if you are volunteering or donating to charity
cons:
Can feel a little culty

If you get a crappy/ not starbucks-y store culture, or a manager obsessed with speed and connection scores, it can really create a toxic environment. 

You need to be someone who can work quickly, keep calm, and smile under pressure. (So I guess that's a con depending on your personality)

If you have a disability and have to deal with corporate, it will be a living hell. I've pushed through it since I have an amazing store, however I know a number of people that have left because of this.

pros: One of the first jobs I truly enjoyed, I loved learning the barista process of creating drinks and meeting such a variety of people. The people I worked with and was able to meet truly made this job fun and I felt a part of something. Training is very streamlined and intense and it gave me that experience I need to work in high paced environments.
cons: Higher ups in the company don't really care beyond stats for each store, drive thru times and sales. It makes sense but there was always a disconnect to our store needs and the lack of care given to us by district managers and even store managers if you happened to work in a lacksluster store. Dealing with transferring to another store has made me realize the overall company isn't really rooting for you, ESPECIALLY how they dealt with the pandemic. Very disappointing.

pros: The culture of learning about coffee and access to the education at ASU are amazing. You get to work with some pretty cool staff and learn a ton about being a Barista
cons:
You get paid way too little to deal with the customer demographic. We had drinks thrown at us, words screamed at us, and we were told to just endure. It's not worth the mental strain in customer service over a $4 drink.

Splitting tips was based on who worked the most hours, but employees that did little to no work would get paid out more than you some weeks, and that was a bitter taste. 

Management (as far as my store was concerned) was absent half of the time, and preyed on the fact that most employees (being they were young) did not know they had access to sick and vacation time.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in San Pablo, CA
pros: They offer free mental health care for 20 sessions a year. They offered additional catastrophe pay to stay home during the beginning of the pandemic, and offer additional COVID sick leave if you have to isolate. They also offer 401k and health/vision/dental at affordable rates. There is room to grow at Starbucks, if you want to move up, my managers have made it very easy and accessible to anyone who has the drive for it.
cons: Customers have gotten a lot more emotional and demanding since the start of the pandemic, and have no issue pushing your boundaries or walking over you. Often times it feels like you are not respected or appreciated by the public. People are more likely to leave a negative review than to leave a positive one. Starbucks has their 3rd place policy, but no decent person is going to listen to you politely reciting company policies, when all they care about is themselves and their cup of coffee. They expect you to bend over backwards for them to matter how nice and cordial you are, and they take advantage of your hospitality and kindness just to pacify them.

I was a closing shift supervisor and if I missed one small thing like restocking apple juice in the display case by the register, I’d get calls and texts the next day harassing me and telling me to do better. That was after staying an hour (sometimes longer) after close.

It really depends on who is hired and how the store runs for how your experience will go. Overall even with these cons, I learned a lot and it was a great stepping stone job for me.
